sets.title: The homing instinct
sets.fullText:
The homing instinct is what makes certain animals, birds and fish return {{0}} to the place they consider home. Cats often have this instinct. It was particularly strong in an American cat called Ninja, which disappeared shortly {{1}} its owners had taken it to their new home; a year later the cat turned up at its old home even {{2}} this was 1,360 kilometres away from {{3}} its owners were now living.

Other cats may not travel so far but many {{4}} on going back to their old home. Pilsbury, an English cat, made a 13-kilometre journey back to its former home 40 times in spite of having to cross several busy roads to {{5}} so.

Pigeons also have the homing instinct and, over {{6}} ancient times, human beings have used them to carry messages back home. However, cat owners, {{7}} have to keep returning to their old address in {{8}} to bring their cat home, tend to find the homing instinct simply irritating rather than useful or interesting!

sets.title: A bicycle you can fold up
sets.fullText:
Folding bicycles have {{0}} around for quite some time now. However, an amazing new Japanese version {{1}} be folded with a swiftness and efficiency never seen before. This bike is designed {{2}} that it is possible to fold it up quickly. Once folded, you pull the bike along {{3}} ease.

This remarkable bike has a half-folding frame with a hinge in the middle. And, although the basic idea is {{4}} original, its inventor has created an especially clever variation, combining compactness {{5}} with smart design.

Recently, folding bicycles {{6}} become very popular in Japan, particularly in congested urban areas like Tokyo, a city {{7}} every square centimetre of space is in great demand. Japanese cyclists need to be able to store their bikes in tiny areas at home or the office. And {{8}} they should want to take their bicycle on the underground, a folding model is a big advantage.

sets.title: An Irish cookery school
sets.fullText:
In the last few years, a number of cookery schools have been set {{0}} in Ireland to promote Irish cooking. {{1}} such school is run by Kathleen Doyle not {{2}} from the centre of Dublin.

'I opened the school twelve years ago,' says Kathleen. 'The school was by no means an overnight success; I found {{3}} necessary to work hard to build up a reputation. One of my advantages was that I'd had problems with my own cooking; I've made {{4}} mistake that it's possible to make, but {{5}} of this, I know what people do wrong from first-hand experience.'

Just {{6}} most cookery schools in Ireland, Kathleen initially copied the classical dishes of France and Italy and other countries {{7}} have a reputation for excellent food. 'Now though, things are changing,' says Kathleen. 'We get excellent produce from Irish farms and, {{8}} a result, we're encouraging students to create unique Irish dishes.'
